content.description: The leftmost climb that lies underneath the Shark Fin. Pretty straight forward, just follow the arrete to the top.
content.protection: Regular rack; lots of stoppers and a few small cams
content.location: Head up towards the shark fin gulley. When you hit a nice ledge, look up at the clear, 30-40ft face and there it is on the left. Right of Sunshine Slab by 200 ft or so.

content.description: The crack just right of Twin Crack Left.
Not climbed very often, approach is very over grown with vegetation. Requires some interesting moves at the top.
content.location: Large crack with a noticeable light colored chock stone. Decend via Shark Fin Gully.

content.description:
The obvious face to the right of Sickle Roof, this route is classic for its position, exposure and view.   

  Scramble up to the base and the crux is right off the ground, then easy protectable climbing to the top. 

  The route can be split up into two pitches and there is a bolt (strange triangle hanger) on a ledge right before the final 20 or 30 feet of the route.  Recommended if you need to supervise a less experienced second.
content.protection: Mostly nuts but a few small cams and TCU's can be helpful.  Larger cams necessary for the anchor at the top of the route.
content.location: Descend via Shark Fin Gully, the obvious gully climber's right of the route.  Requires some 4th class to traverse to from the top of the route.  It is a good idea to shortrope or spot inexperienced partners.

content.description: This is the awesome looking orange streaked wall to the left of the Sickle. There are bolts, and the moves are sporty, but be prepared to look for funky pro between bolts. Start up the Sickle corner and break out left a little ways up on an obvious boulder problem. Then continue up the ramp to the right towards bigger holds and a weakness in the bulge.
content.protection: Four quick-draws, a single set of small to medium cams and a rack of nuts. Anchors at top.
content.location: Left wall of the lower Sickle corner.

content.description:
Climb Sickle (5.10a) but instead of continuing to traverse under the roof, go straight out over the roof. a V5 boulder problem is the crux of this roof. If the roof proofs to be to challenging, you can still bust out right under the roof to finish on Sickles ending moves. 

  Make sure the second is tall enough to reach the gear in the roof!! you will have to leave it if they cant.
content.location: Left of Sunshine Slab, follow slab up to corner of Sickle, follow corner up and out the middle of the roof.

content.description: run up the 80 foot 5.4 slab without gear and get to the corner. The corner is the real deal of the climb. Small gear, stemming and smearing will get you up the corner, traverse right under Sickle Roof, turning to the right and up a gully to the summit.

A cool route with an airy, ascending traverse in the middle. Expect a variety of climbing techniques. Lots of great holds and good feet. The crux is an awkward, wide section just off the deck. Can be broken into two pitches but also climbs fine as one with a 60 meter rope. Use slings to manage rope drag.
content.protection: All traditional. Gear can be somewhat tricky and is runout in spots, particularly the 2nd pitch. Small to large cams and stoppers. Placements range from good to funky or marginal. #4 Camalot useful for crux. It also looks possible to sling the chock-stone.
content.location: Just right of the Shark Fin Gully. Start beneath a medium sized, brushy oak and head toward an off-width crack with a chock-stone in it about 18' up.

content.description: I haven't climbed this on over 5 years so I don't remember many details other than it being an easy ramp. You can break this up into two pitches but it should go as one. The decent is the same as Sunshine Slab: a series of down scrambling and traversing to the Shark-Fin gully.
content.protection: Nuts, Cams, and Hexes. Single Rack up to #4 BD Cams.
content.location: The ramp just to the right of Sunshine Slab

content.description: Just right of the Yellow Edge. Climb the face, along a few winding cracks, through a triangular pod.
content.protection: Regular rack; heavy on the stoppers.
content.location: Up in the Shark Fin Gulley, in between the Yellow Edge and the hidden chimney.

content.description: Start by climbing up small crack. Continue up until you reach a large belay ledge. For the second pitch keep toward the "waffle" rock texture. Tops out just left of Heart Route.
content.protection: Small cams and slings are useful.
content.location: Start at the same location as Heart Route. Descend through Shark Fin Gully.

content.description: Left facing crack system immediately left of Sunshine Slab. The route is named for a committing boulder move just before the fixed bolt, protect with medium sized nut. To finish, link up with  Sunshine Slab or climb the West face for a variation.
content.location: A short scramble up and to the left of Sunshine Slab.

content.description: Directly underneath the Shark Fin, this climb keeps you completely covered. Head up lots of meandering cracks to a horizontal. Follow the horizontal to the right and take one of two finishes; backwards onto a high block, then up the face to the top, or up the wide crack to the left and pull the roof.
content.protection: Small nuts, run out the first 20 or so feet
content.location: In the Shark Fin Gulley, right of Rigging, directly underneath the Shark Fin

content.description: This is the sunniest part of Thumb Butte and can sizzle shoes in the hot months but also provide for decent climbing during the cold.  Most routes are low-angle and allow for very creative protection and nutcraft.  A few bolted routes exist as well as some crack sections, but most climbs are face climbing with natural pro.
